review.title: Predicting health inspection results from online restaurant reviews
review.abstract: Informatics around public health are increasingly shifting from the professional to the public spheres. In this work, we apply linguistic analytics to restaurant reviews, from Yelp, in order to automatically predict official health inspection reports. We consider two types of feature sets, i.e., keyword detection and topic model features, and use these in several classification methods. Our empirical analysis shows that these extracted features can predict public health inspection reports with over 90% accuracy using simple support vector machines.

metadata.title: Predicting health inspection results from online restaurant reviews

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: Normally, official restaurant health and safety audits are conducted only once to three times a year and include fixed food safety checklists. 3 Meanwhile, reviews of these restaurants are published much more frequently on sites such as Yelp and TripAdvisor. This, of course, leads to the question of whether restaurant reviews can support the process of public health inspection by identifying potentially risky restaurants that require more frequent inspections.To answer this question, we compare official results of inspections of Kitchener-Waterloo restaurants with text comments found in Yelp reviews of those restaurants. Specifically, we extract a number of key words and theme model features and apply them to some classification methods. Our extracted features can predict public health inspection with 90% accuracy when used with an assisting vector machine (SVM).

sections.heading: 2 Data
sections.text: In our study, we use Yelp4 and Waterloo Public Health (WPH) 5 data. We extract plant information and official inspection results (date, type, and recommended actions) from WPH. From Yelp, we extract business information (matched with WPH plant information) and tokenize text ratings. These tokens are used in a document term matrix and serve as characteristics in this work. The other characteristics are learned topic models, i.e. the distribution of topics for each topic learned. We use binary predictive labels: "action" that indicates non-compliance or some other major problem with the restaurant, and "no action" when the restaurant passes the health inspection.

sections.heading: 4 Conclusion
sections.text: Text analysis from Yelp reviews can clearly be used to predict the results of official health inspections, as evidenced by over 90% accuracy in predicting official WPH actions based on learned keywords and subject model features in an SVM classifier. Reducing the total number of keywords to an optimized subset in both the NBA and SVM approaches significantly improves performance, which is most likely to lead to potential overmatch in full. Given that both sensitivity and sensitivity are very high in our optimal system, there is strong evidence that this tool, or a very similar one, can be used by governments to optimize their resources. Specifically, inspection plans should be generated automatically from crowdsourced data, as in this work, and by default regulated procedures. Deriving such schedules is the subject of future work. Other possible ways of exploring include online sourcing interactive health reports, combined with crowd-inspection databases, and public health reports.
